text: uh hey everyone ear the knee popped in
here the Internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of the new
tame impala record the slow rush this is
a brand new full-length LP from Kevin
Parker's tame impala it has been five
whole years since the release of the
Bands last record currents and that span
of time frankly has felt like forever
mostly because that record came along
with such incredible crossover success
hitting it big not only with pop fans
but hip hop fans too by bringing more
keys and punchy beats into the fold so
with this new LP I've been curious as to
whether or not we're going to see
another big stylistic change but the
slow Rush is pretty much another helping
of ethereal falsetto psyche from Kevin
Parker which is okay I mean this time
around the synths aren't nearly as
pumped up or as novel as they were on
currents the grooves are certainly still
there though many of them feel a bit
more disco influenced I guess but what
makes the slow rush stand out in the
tame impala discography or at least what
had me excited to listen to it was that
the teaser track seemed like they were
taking a pretty introspective and
personal turn a lot of themes having to
do with memory and past experiences time
passing as well like on lost and
yesterday and posthumous forgiveness it
might be time Kevin is really using
these dreamy psychedelic beds of
instrumentation to explore some very
serious personal pain and from the
singles it sounded like he didn't need
to kneecap the instrumentals or the
songwriting to make it happen like on
posthumous forgiveness which features
these twinkly sad guitar leads set to
some very airy and dramatic organs it
feels like I'm exploring or him just
lost in an endless desert waiting for
heatstroke to take me Kevin on this
track is singing his heart out about his
estranged father he's gone now and he
wishes that he had the ability to
reconnect with him and tell him about
his new life and everything that music
has brought him and I guess try to
reconcile some of this hurt I love the
rushes of glassy chords the woozy synth
leads the instrumental switch up in the
second half it's a very beautiful
dramatic compelling multi-phase track we
get more infectious grooves and bass on
lost in yesterday with Kevin once again
lyrically dwelling on the
asked with the other cut it might be
time that T's toward this record we have
Kevin anxious over his coolness his
relevancy his ability to I guess keep up
with things creatively in stay popular
in the field of music it's sort of like
his very own LCD Soundsystem's losing my
edge the beat certainly goes almost as
hard that's for sure with the sirens
since the massive distorted bass also
some pretty sharp delays on the vocals
too it's maybe the closest thing this
album has to a rager and sure while it
was a little too easygoing for my ears
the track borderline I thought was a
decent taster for this record - in fact
the beat on this thing and some of the
vocalizations along with the slightly
dreamy aesthetic reminded me of like a
gorilla's track maybe if things were
more up front and there were a vocal
guest or two on it it certainly could be
honestly I'm just happy patience didn't
end up being on this record because that
was a bland single so going into this I
was pretty excited that I would like the
whole thing especially given how good
these teaser tracks were and also just
that I've generally been sad that I
don't tend to enjoy Curren as much as
many fans do and have always thought
tame impala could do better and maybe
this will be that record but the deep
cuts on this thing do reveal some
redundancies and a lack of creativity on
the sound play side of things as well
something I think is pretty key to the
psyche genre generally while the reverb
on this thing and the delays and the
bright sheen on most of these tracks do
check some basic boxes I'll say this
this is no Flaming Lips when it comes to
Sonic excursions it's not even really
much of an MGMT either if you really
want an example of how texturally
unadventurous this project is then maybe
give a listen to the song instant
destiny Kevin's opening vocal melody on
the track is pretty good actually I
don't really mind the tune all that much
but come on sonically
this thing is pretty toothless muddy
booming drums washy cents very bass -
all mushing together in a loud but
somehow lifeless display of sound the
bass and crisp drums on breathe deeper
are much better but it doesn't take too
long for this track as well
to get enveloped in the same palette of
effects which frankly at this point are
quite obvious and Kevin can't seem to
diverge from them in any meaningful way
eventually the track turns tedious as it
extends past four minutes
going into passageways that maybe you
should have saved for some kind of
12-inch dance mix or something then
after that it's the songs themselves
that begin turning forgettable like on
the track tomorrow's dust the two chord
progression on this track it comes off
as uninspired before we're even a minute
in and Kevin layering more and more
instrumentation on top of it doesn't
make it any more appealing there's also
the oddly derivative one more year which
on the surface might seem like any old
tame impala track but hear me out the
linear driving groove on this song and
the way that Kevin is poetically riffing
over this instrumental it kind of
reminds me of like some fear of music or
remain in light era Talking Heads but
obviously way dream ear in typical tame
impala fashion but Kevin doesn't come
off in the track with enough
eccentricity or presence to really sell
it the greatest deep cut this thing has
to offer is easily the song on track
which is a stunning ballad with powerful
keys spotlit lead vocals some dramatic
drums - it sounds like an idyllic dreamy
image of the 70s with lyrics about
getting up dusting yourself off getting
back on track after horrible things have
been thrown into your lap the records
final leg I think is ok especially given
it might be time and lost in yesterday
the song it is true does save one of the
nastiest grooves for the end of the LP
though it's not one of the stronger
songs here it does kind of bow out
without having developed anything
significant and glimmer is kind of dull
two-minute interlude that wasn't
entirely necessary and the random I
guess studio bit of banter about
cranking the kick up if you want the
kick to sound great and crank and the
bass up if you want the bass it sound
great doesn't necessarily hold true in
all cases and may be indicative of the
production problems this album suffers
from occasionally case in point the
final song one more hour which I do
appreciate stylistically
a switch up here as it's one of the more
prog influenced songs on the project but
the vocals and the shimmering synth runs
on this thing shouldn't be nearly as
buried as they actually are and this
track is really a point where the
records claustrophobic production ends
up hurting it in a big way as all of
these explosions of instrumentation just
feel a little neutered they don't hit as
hard as they could nor do they feel all
that clear just a little muddy a little
muffled I guess once more I do like that
Kevin tried to get a little ambitious
with this closer and the stripped back
passages on this track of vocals and
keys do bring some much-needed drama to
the song too but the whole final leg of
this track is a total waste as Kevin
just decides to I guess feed the whole
goddamn thing through a phaser and it
just sounds like just combining mush
with more mush to create this giant orgy
of mush at this point we're just goofing
off with the same handful of effects
that we're placing on almost every other
song here so while I do think that this
record does have some good songs to its
name and a very cool pillowy exterior
that is vaguely psychedelic there are
some moments here where yeah the vocals
are a bit weak the songwriting isn't
quite there and the very uniform sound
and style throughout the entire album
does get quite old I mean for a
psychedelic act taemin pilot doesn't
have nearly as much sonic versatility as
I would like on a record especially one
that is nearing an hour in length so
while I do think this is decent and
hardcore fans of currents are most
likely going to enjoy it more than me it
could have been better feeling a decent
two strong six on this one transition
